attachments.text: The ultimate precision in the measurement of the muon anomaly, $a_\mu$ = (g – 2)/2, has been constantly pursued since the sixties, when CERN played a leading role in its determination with a series of pioneering experiments that ran until the late seventies. The present most accurate $a_\mu$ measurement was carried out by the E821 Experiment at Brookhaven (USA), resulting in a 3.7 standard deviation discrepancy with the theoretical prediction of the Standard Model of particle physics. text: <@U010LT79LKX> Well, let's just put it that way: every new physics we discover eventually has a practical application. Modern electronics (i.e. the device on which you made your comment) wouldn't be possible if we didn't have Quantum Mechanics. GPS wouldn't be possible if we didn't have General Relativity. So it's more than just a search to better our scientific understanding of the world (although on its own it's very valuable already). Every bit of new physics will eventually lead to some application, although there is no way anyone can know what they will be (Einstein certainly didn't have the GPS in mind when he wrote his General Relativity Theory). So every bit of evidence that may help us understand where our current theories fail and why they fail is extremely exciting!

True. But believe me when I say most of that speculation will be based on existing theories (like String Theory). We're unlikely to see anything really brand new before we're sure the deviation is real and we can measure some of its properties.
The main problem is that we're only just starting to have the technology for this kind of experimentation. It'll take a while before we start to get a clear experimental picture of what's happening.

text: I still don't get what you want. The Standard Model is only dense and impenetrable because our common sense is based on macro events, and particles themselves just don't behave that way. Let go of that need to connect everything to macro events and you'll be all the better for it. Well, if nobody else is going to say it, I’ll say it. Practically nobody thinks that Beyond Standard Model physics will change anything for anyone in a practical sense.

There are no proposed technologies that rely even on anything more exotic than up quarks, down quarks and electrons in tha standard model, let alone beyond standard model physics. The reason the standard model seems so abstract and disconnected from your experience is because it is. 

The energy scales at which these effects lie are truly immense and are incredibly unlikely to have any signatures at more practical scales.

text: Of course, we don’t know for sure. We could discover something that’s very useful, but there really doesn’t appear to be a good reason to think that right now. It’s good to be open minded and to not be blinded by the success of our models, but the situation right now is really not analogous to the situation at the dawn of quantum mechanics.
